docs.snippet: Federal agents raided three medical marijuana clubs, in San Francisco, Oakland and Petaluma, arresting four people and adding fuel to a dispute between local and federal officials. The administrator of the Drug Enforcement Administration, Asa Hutc...
docs.lead_paragraph: Federal agents raided three medical marijuana clubs, in San Francisco, Oakland and Petaluma, arresting four people and adding fuel to a dispute between local and federal officials. The administrator of the Drug Enforcement Administration, Asa Hutchinson, met a hostile audience later in the day at the Commonwealth Club in San Francisco as he explained the Bush Administration's stepped up drug war. The San Francisco district attorney, Terence Hallinan, said that city officials had not been informed of the raid and that it and Mr. Hutchinson's simultaneous visit were the latest insults in an ongoing battle between local and federal officials. ''The city's chief law officials do not agree with the federal government's actions,'' Mr. Hallinan said. Mr. Hutchinson said the raid was apolitical and reflected the drug agency's responsibility to uphold federal law.
docs.abstract: Federal agents raid three medical marijuana clubs in San Francisco, Oakland and Petaluma, arresting four people and adding fuel to dispute between local and federal officials (S)

docs.snippet: The Copperhead Mayor    Q. Norman Mailer and Jimmy Breslin campaigned to make New York City the 51st state in their legendary 1969 mayoral bid. Have any mayors entertained similar ideas?    A. Fernando Wood, who was mayor when the Civil War broke ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Copperhead Mayor Q. Norman Mailer and Jimmy Breslin campaigned to make New York City the 51st state in their legendary 1969 mayoral bid. Have any mayors entertained similar ideas? A. Fernando Wood, who was mayor when the Civil War broke out in April 1861, had proposed in January that if the Union should break up, New York City should not only become a separate state but also secede.
docs.abstract: FYI column answers questions about mayors who have pushed to make New York City state, how long subway doors stay open and who decides, and reason for bare light bulbs in Grand Central Terminal's chandeliers; drawing (M)

docs.snippet: NOBLE-Marshall Hays, 78 years old. Of Pawcatuck, CT, died of cancer January 8, 2002, at Lawrence & Memorial Hospital in New London, CT. He was the beloved husband of Carolie Woods Noble and devoted stepfather of five Hollingsworth chldren. He was ...
docs.lead_paragraph: NOBLE-Marshall Hays, 78 years old. Of Pawcatuck, CT, died of cancer January 8, 2002, at Lawrence & Memorial Hospital in New London, CT. He was the beloved husband of Carolie Woods Noble and devoted stepfather of five Hollingsworth chldren. He was a graduate of Culver Military Academy and Princeton University. After serving in the US Army special forces in World War II, he was a career Foreign Service officer in the United States Department of State, with extensive postings in Southeast Asia. He was Deputy Chief of Mission in Luxembourg. Services will be held Saturday, 1 PM Jan. 12, at the Calvary Church, 27 Church St., Stonington, CT. Contributions will be appreciated by the Community Cancer Center, Lawrence & Memorial Hospital, 365 Montauk Ave., New London, CT 06320, or Visiting Nurses Assoc. of Southeastern Conn., 403 North Frontage Rd, Waterford, CT 06385.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOBLE, MARSHALL HAYS

docs.snippet: With the collapse of Al Qaeda forces in Tora Bora and the installation of a new, if shaky, government in Afghanistan, the Bush administration is putting out two messages: It's not over till it's over, and even when this first phase of the war does...
docs.lead_paragraph: With the collapse of Al Qaeda forces in Tora Bora and the installation of a new, if shaky, government in Afghanistan, the Bush administration is putting out two messages: It's not over till it's over, and even when this first phase of the war does end, Mr. Bush plans to move quickly to other terrorist havens. Still, as the White House is learning, articulating those messages on the talk shows is one thing. Carrying them out from the Situation Room is a lot trickier.
docs.abstract: Analysis of Bush administration's messages following collapse of Al Qaeda forces in Tora Bora and installation of new, if shaky, government in Afghanistan; White House says first phase of its war on terrorism has ended; pledges to move quickly to other terrorist havens; politics of where to go next grow ever more complex; it is not clear how quickly Pres Bush can extract American troops from Afghanistan or where he should next take war on terrorism; Washington officials pointedly refuse to echo exuberant declarations of victory issued by anti-Taliban forces; Bush's central goal, capturing or killing Osama bin Laden and his lieutenants, remains largely unfulfilled (M)

docs.snippet: An obituary on Wednesday about Ernest van den Haag, a Dutch-born conservative commentator on social issues, misidentified the regime by which he told friends he had been detained in the 1930's. It was the Fascist regime in Italy, not the Nazis in ...
docs.lead_paragraph: An obituary on Wednesday about Ernest van den Haag, a Dutch-born conservative commentator on social issues, misidentified the regime by which he told friends he had been detained in the 1930's. It was the Fascist regime in Italy, not the Nazis in the Netherlands. The obituary also gave an incomplete version of Dr. van den Haag's account of his escapes from internment and misstated the sequence of events. In the account, supplied by National Review from his coming obituary, Dr. van den Haag said he escaped from the Fascists at 19 and fled to France. He also said that the French interned him as an enemy alien after the start of World War II, but that he escaped to Portugal and then to the United States. He did not tell of having reached the United States directly from the Netherlands.
docs.abstract: Correction of March 27 obituary about Ernest van den Haag; his experiences in World War II noted

docs.snippet: SHEN-Shih-Chang. Of San Francisco, CA, formerly of Hamden, CT, died on March 5, 2002 at the age of 90. Born in Shanghai, China, he received his BS from Yenching University, his MD from Peking Union Medical College, and his PhD from Cambridge Unive...
docs.lead_paragraph: SHEN-Shih-Chang. Of San Francisco, CA, formerly of Hamden, CT, died on March 5, 2002 at the age of 90. Born in Shanghai, China, he received his BS from Yenching University, his MD from Peking Union Medical College, and his PhD from Cambridge University, England. Dr. Shen was named director of the National Institute of Physiology in Shanghai, but the outbreak of World War II prevented him from returning to his homeland to assume that post. From 1948 to 1958 he was a professor of zoology at Yale University and from 1958 to 1975 he taught in the field of anatomy and neurophysiology at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons. He is survived by his wife Clara; his son Theodore, his daughters Linda Shen, Joan Woo and Corinne Wong; six grandchildren and six great-grandchildren.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEN, SHIH, CHANG

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Four times Michael Kimmelman refers to the Vietnam Veterans Memorial as being by Maya Lin. In fact, only half of it -- the black granite wall bearing the names of soldiers dead or missing -- is by her. The other half consists of ...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Four times Michael Kimmelman refers to the Vietnam Veterans Memorial as being by Maya Lin. In fact, only half of it -- the black granite wall bearing the names of soldiers dead or missing -- is by her. The other half consists of a bronze group of three soldiers in combat gear by Frederick Hart, one of America's leading sculptors until his death in 1999. Mr. Kimmelman does not even mention his name.
docs.abstract: Michelle Marder Kamhi letter on Michael Kimmelman's January 13 article on World Trade Center memorial notes that Maya Lin and Frederick Hart designed two parts of Vietnam Veterans Memorial; photo

docs.snippet: SEBALD-W.G. The 92nd Street Y Board and staff mourn the passing of novelist W.G. Sebald. On October 15, 2001, Sebald graced the stage of the Unterberg Poetry Center, reading from his novel, ''Austerlitz''. The Y honors Sebald's stylistic bravery a...
docs.lead_paragraph: SEBALD-W.G. The 92nd Street Y Board and staff mourn the passing of novelist W.G. Sebald. On October 15, 2001, Sebald graced the stage of the Unterberg Poetry Center, reading from his novel, ''Austerlitz''. The Y honors Sebald's stylistic bravery and depictions of life in the aftermath of World War II and the Holocaust. His death is a blow to literature, but his work is a gift. We send our thoughts and prayers to his family. Matthew Bronfman, President Philip L. Milstein, Chairman Sol Adler, Executive Director, 92nd Street Y Hanna Arie-Gaifman, Director, 92nd Street Y, Tisch Center for the Arts David Yezzi, Director, 92nd Street Y, Unterberg Poetry Center

docs.snippet: CLARKE-Francis K. (Frank or Kenny). Of East Meadow on December 15th in his 78th year. (Veteran of World War II A.A.F. member of VFW Post Franklin Sq. and retired pressroom Supervisor at The New York Times). Loving husband of Josephine. Devoted fat...
docs.lead_paragraph: CLARKE-Francis K. (Frank or Kenny). Of East Meadow on December 15th in his 78th year. (Veteran of World War II A.A.F. member of VFW Post Franklin Sq. and retired pressroom Supervisor at The New York Times). Loving husband of Josephine. Devoted father of Michael (Sandra), Kenneth, and Jeffrey. Cherished grandfather of Michael. Fond brother of John E. and the late Harold, Philip, Clarence, James, Edna, Mary, Katherine and Ruth. Frank is survived by many nieces and nephews. Friends may call Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home Inc., Levittown Chapel, 2786 Hempstead Turnpike (2 blocks east of the Wantagh Parkway). Mass is on Wednesday 10:00 AM at the Holy Family R.C. Church, Hicksville. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARKE, FRANCIS K. (FRANK OR KENNY)
